description: Single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) has emerged as a central genome-wide method to characterize cellular identities and processes. Consequently, improving its sensitivity, flexibility and cost-efficiency can advance many research questions. Among the flexible plate-based methods, “Single-Cell RNA-Barcoding and Sequencing” (SCRB-seq) is one of the most sensitive and efficient ones. Here, we systematically evaluated experimental conditions of this protocol and find that adding polyethylene glycol considerably increases sensitivity by enhancing cDNA synthesis. Furthermore, using Terra polymerase increases efficiency due to a more even cDNA amplification that requires less sequencing of libraries. We combined these and other improvements to a new scRNA-seq library protocol we call “molecular crowding SCRB-seq” (mcSCRB-seq), which we show to be  the most sensitive and one of the most efficient and flexible scRNA-seq methods to date.
before_start: Wipe bench surfaces with RNAse Away and keep working environment clean.

materials.reagent_name: Bioanalyzer High Sensitivity DNA Analysis Kits
Nextera XT DNA Library Preparation Kit

groups.group_name: Human Cell Atlas Method Development Community

authors: Johannes Bagnoli,Christoph Ziegenhain,Aleksandar Janjic,Lucas Esteban Wange,Beate Vieth,Swati Parekh,Johanna Geuder,Ines Hellmann,Wolfgang Enard
guidelines:
• The complete list of reagents and plastic ware with order numbers can be found in the 'Materials' section.

 

  • Make sure all steps involving single-cell lysate and RNA before reverse transcription are carried out swiftly.

 

  • Size selection of libraries is optional, but has in our experience improved reliability in cluster densities when sequencing. 

 

  • All primer sequences are listed below:

 

Oligo Vendor Purification Concentration Sequence

barcoded oligo-dT (E3V6NEXT)

 IDT

TruGrade

2 µM

Biotin-ACACTCTTTCCCTACACGACGCTCTTCCGATCT[BC6][UMI10][T30]VN

TSO unblocked (E5V6NEXT)

 IDT HPLC 100 µM

ACACTCTTTCCCTACACGACGCrGrGrG
PreAmp (SINGV6) IDT Desalted 10 µM

Biotin-ACACTCTTTCCCTACACGACGC
 3' enrichment primer (P5NEXTPT5) IDT HPLC 5 µM  

AATGATACGGCGACCACCGAGATCTACACTCTTTCCCTACACGACGCTCTTCCG*A*T*C*T

i7 Index Primer (N7XX)

 IDT TruGrade 5 µM

CAAGCAGAAGACGGCATACGAGAT[i7]GTCTCGTGGGCTCGG

 

Find the cell barcode sequences in the attached text file (Abstract tab).
status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

components.data:
Prepare 96/384 well plate(s) containing 4 μL Lysis Buffer per well.

 

Add 1 μL barcoded oligo-dT primer [2 μM] (E3V6NEXT adapter) to each well (12-/64-channel pipette).

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 2 of mcSCRB-seq protocol
source_data.annotation: Thanks for sharing this outstanding resource. I was wondering if you tested the importance of the biotin modification of the oligo-dT primer? Just as you found that unblocked TSO's weren't superior to blocked TSO, I'm wondering if the biotin modification is really necessary to prevent concatemeters. The major upfront cost is the barcoded primer, so anything that reduces the costs of these primers would make the protocol even more cost effective.
source_data.thread_text: Thanks for sharing this outstanding resource. I was wondering if you tested the importance of the biotin modification of the oligo-dT primer? Just as you found that unblocked TSO's weren't superior to blocked TSO, I'm wondering if the biotin modification is really necessary to prevent concatemeters. The major upfront cost is the barcoded primer, so anything that reduces the costs of these primers would make the protocol even more cost effective.
source_data.body: Thanks for sharing this outstanding resource. I was wondering if you tested the importance of the biotin modification of the oligo-dT primer? Just as you found that unblocked TSO's weren't superior to blocked TSO, I'm wondering if the biotin modification is really necessary to prevent concatemeters. The major upfront cost is the barcoded primer, so anything that reduces the costs of these primers would make the protocol even more cost effective.

comments.name: Alexander Chamessian
comments.comment_text: I agree. I'd like to know. Not having the biotin would make primer purchasing easier and cheaper. And is the TruGrade necessary?
comments.body: I agree. I'd like to know. Not having the biotin would make primer purchasing easier and cheaper. And is the TruGrade necessary?

comments.name: Aleksandar Janjic
comments.comment_text: Thanks Brian. We have not tested oligodTs without biotin but we have tested the SINGV6 primer (the one for pre-amplification) with and without biotin. The one with biotin gave us more yield. I am not exactly sure how this would translate to the oligodT primers though, however, this is something that's on our to-do list.
comments.body: Thanks Brian. We have not tested oligodTs without biotin but we have tested the SINGV6 primer (the one for pre-amplification) with and without biotin. The one with biotin gave us more yield. I am not exactly sure how this would translate to the oligodT primers though, however, this is something that's on our to-do list.

comments.name: Christoph Ziegenhain
comments.comment_text:
Thanks for your feedback - I think this is a great discussion. The biotin moiety has been used a lot in single-cell approaches to prevent formation of primer dimers or other artifacts.

Another interesting consideration in my opinion is that it could make mcSCRB-seq compatible with multi-omics approaches such as G&T-seq. 

https://www.nature.com/articles/nmeth.3370
comments.body:
Thanks for your feedback - I think this is a great discussion. The biotin moiety has been used a lot in single-cell approaches to prevent formation of primer dimers or other artifacts.

Another interesting consideration in my opinion is that it could make mcSCRB-seq compatible with multi-omics approaches such as G&T-seq. 

https://www.nature.com/articles/nmeth.3370

comments.name: Brian Muegge
comments.comment_text: Thank you Aleksandar and Christoph. Agreed that the biotin has been used in many other methods, and Christoph your point about separation of mRNA's from genomic DNA is an interesting one. Some protocols (e.g. Cel-seq) don't use the biotin modification. From what I can tell, the biotin modification was implemented with SMART-seq and has been passed down since, though I don't think I've seen a head-to-head comparison using 3' methods. We are gathering reagents and a small number of barcoded primers for pilot studies with single cells and nuclei. I will start with primers that are not biotin modified and share the results when we receive them.
comments.body: Thank you Aleksandar and Christoph. Agreed that the biotin has been used in many other methods, and Christoph your point about separation of mRNA's from genomic DNA is an interesting one. Some protocols (e.g. Cel-seq) don't use the biotin modification. From what I can tell, the biotin modification was implemented with SMART-seq and has been passed down since, though I don't think I've seen a head-to-head comparison using 3' methods. We are gathering reagents and a small number of barcoded primers for pilot studies with single cells and nuclei. I will start with primers that are not biotin modified and share the results when we receive them.

comments.name: Alexander Chamessian
comments.comment_text: Please let us know how it goes. Thinking about this more, if the goal is to reduce primer dimers, that step would most likely happen at the cDNA amp step. And by that point, the residual primers have been degraded by Exonuclease I anyway. So unless the biotin modification does something with the single round of RT, it probably is dispensable.
comments.body: Please let us know how it goes. Thinking about this more, if the goal is to reduce primer dimers, that step would most likely happen at the cDNA amp step. And by that point, the residual primers have been degraded by Exonuclease I anyway. So unless the biotin modification does something with the single round of RT, it probably is dispensable.

components.data:
Prepare Pooling Beads:

 

 

 Reagent Amount
PEG 8000

15 g

NaCl, 5M

 20 mL

Tris-HCL, 1M, pH 8.0

 500 μL

EDTA, 0.5M

100 μL

IGEPAL, 10% solution

 50 μL

Sodium Azide, 10% solution

 250 μL
UltraPure Water up to 50 mL
Total  50 mL

 

  • Add all ingredients into a 50 mL falcon tube, but do not add the total amount of water until after PEG is completely solubilized
  • Incubate at 40°C and vortex regularly until PEG is completely dissolved
  • Resuspend bead stock carefully (Sera-Mag Speed Beads)
  • Pipette 100 μL of bead suspension into a 96-well plate well
  • Place on magnet stand
  • Remove supernatant
  • Add 100 μL 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 1 mM EDTA (TE), and resuspend beads
  • Place on magnet stand
  • Remove supernatant
  • Repeat wash one more time
  • Add 90 μL 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 1 mM EDTA (TE), and resuspend beads
  • Add to PEG solution above and mix well.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 14 of mcSCRB-seq protocol
source_data.annotation: For 384, is this literally aspirating well by well, one at a time? Or do you all have a way to automate? I can envision aspirating into a trough, but there would likely be loss.
source_data.thread_text: For 384, is this literally aspirating well by well, one at a time? Or do you all have a way to automate? I can envision aspirating into a trough, but there would likely be loss.
source_data.body: For 384, is this literally aspirating well by well, one at a time? Or do you all have a way to automate? I can envision aspirating into a trough, but there would likely be loss.

comments.name: Christoph Ziegenhain
comments.comment_text: So losses should be strictly avoided because the material is not amplified yet. What we usually do is using a multichannel pipette to pool everything from the 384 well plate into a 96 well plate. Then in a second step you can transfer the RT products into a tube. We have noted that DNA low binding plastic ware seems to help, so be sure to check out our recommendations of plates and tubes in the "Materials" section.
comments.body: So losses should be strictly avoided because the material is not amplified yet. What we usually do is using a multichannel pipette to pool everything from the 384 well plate into a 96 well plate. Then in a second step you can transfer the RT products into a tube. We have noted that DNA low binding plastic ware seems to help, so be sure to check out our recommendations of plates and tubes in the "Materials" section.

components.data:
For 96-well plates: Pool all wells of one plate into a 2 mL tube and add 960 μL (ratio 1/1) 30% PEG Pooling Beads

For 384-well plates: Pool all wells of one plate into a 15 mL falcon tube and add 3840 μL (ratio 1/1) 30% PEG Pooling Beads

In a thermocycler with heated lead, incubate as follows:

Step Temperature Time Cycles
Initial Denaturation 98 °C 3 min 1x
Denaturation 98 °C 15 sec

 

 13-21x
Annealing 65 °C 30 sec
Elongation 68 °C 4 min
Final Elongation 72 °C 10 min

 

 1x
Store 8 °C

∞

source_data.annotation: Cylce number highly depends on the input amount and should be optimized depending on the specific celltype used in the experiment. For ES cells, 13-15 cycles are sufficient.

Prepare Clean-up Beads:

 

 

 Reagent Amount
PEG 8000

11 g

NaCl, 5M

 10 mL

Tris-HCL, 1M, pH 8.0

 500 μL

EDTA, 0.5M

100 μL

IGEPAL, 10% solution

 50 μL

Sodium Azide, 10% solution

 250 μL
UltraPure Water up to 49 mL
Total  49 mL

 

  • Add all ingredients into a 50 mL falcon tube, but do not add the total amount of water until after PEG is completely solubilized
  • Incubate at 40°C and vortex regularly until PEG is completely dissolved
  • Resuspend bead stock carefully (Sera-Mag Speed Beads)
  • Pipette 1000 μL of bead suspension into a 1.5 mL tube
  • Place on magnet stand
  • Remove supernatant
  • Add 1000 μL 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 1 mM EDTA (TE), and resuspend beads
  • Place on magnet stand
  • Remove supernatant
  • Repeat wash one more time
  • Add 900 μL 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 1 mM EDTA (TE), and resuspend beads
  • Add to PEG solution above and mix well.

components.data: Wash twice with 150 µL 80% ethanol (while on magnet) and discard supernatant

components.data: Load complete library onto an 2% Agarose E-Gel EX and run for 10 minutes.

components.data: As soon as the Gel run has finished open the Gel framing using the Gel opening tool

components.data: Excise the Library from 300bp to 900bp using a clean scalpel
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Excise the Library from 300bp to 900bp using a clean scalpel

components.data:
Gel purify the slice using the Qiagen MinElute Kit following manufacturer's guidelines:

  • Add 450 µL Buffer QG
  • Dissolve the gel slice in QG for 10 min @ 42 °C
  • Add 150 μL Isopropanol to the sample and mix by inverting
  • Transfer sample to spin column and centrifuge at 16 000 x g for 1 min
  • Discard flow through and add 500 μL Buffer QG
  • Centrifuge at 16 000 x g for 1 min and discard flow through
  • Add 700 μL Buffer PE
  • Centrifuge at 16 000 x g for 1 min and discard flow through
  • Centrifuge again at 16 000 x g for 1 min to remove residual ethanol
  • Transfer column to a new 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube
  • Add 20 μL H2O to column and incubate for 1 min
  • Centrifuge at 16 000 x g for 1 min to elute and discard the spin column
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Gel purify the slice using the Qiagen MinElute Kit following manufacturer's guidelines:

  • Add 450 µL Buffer QG
  • Dissolve the gel slice in QG for 10 min @ 42 °C
  • Add 150 μL Isopropanol to the sample and mix by inverting
  • Transfer sample to spin column and centrifuge at 16 000 x g for 1 min
  • Discard flow through and add 500 μL Buffer QG
  • Centrifuge at 16 000 x g for 1 min and discard flow through
  • Add 700 μL Buffer PE
  • Centrifuge at 16 000 x g for 1 min and discard flow through
  • Centrifuge again at 16 000 x g for 1 min to remove residual ethanol
  • Transfer column to a new 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube
  • Add 20 μL H2O to column and incubate for 1 min
  • Centrifuge at 16 000 x g for 1 min to elute and discard the spin column

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 52 of mcSCRB-seq protocol
source_data.annotation: Any reason why you used gel purification for size selection vs. double-sided bead clean up? Would the latter not work?
source_data.thread_text: Any reason why you used gel purification for size selection vs. double-sided bead clean up? Would the latter not work?
source_data.body: Any reason why you used gel purification for size selection vs. double-sided bead clean up? Would the latter not work?

comments.name: Christoph Ziegenhain
comments.comment_text: We've had pretty good experience with the gel purification, but there is no reason why beads shouldn't work.
comments.body: We've had pretty good experience with the gel purification, but there is no reason why beads shouldn't work.

components.data:
Quantify and quality control the library using the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer with High Sensitivity DNA Analysis Kits.

Load both the library and a 1/10 dilution on two different lanes of the chip.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Quantify and quality control the library using the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer with High Sensitivity DNA Analysis Kits.

Load both the library and a 1/10 dilution on two different lanes of the chip.

source_data.annotation: If cDNA was not quality controlled previously, it is strongly suggested to run cDNA on the same chip.
source_data.thread_text: If cDNA was not quality controlled previously, it is strongly suggested to run cDNA on the same chip.
source_data.body: If cDNA was not quality controlled previously, it is strongly suggested to run cDNA on the same chip.

components.data: Successful libraries will typically exceed 3-5 ng/μl concentration.
components.name: Expected result

source_data.result: Successful libraries will typically exceed 3-5 ng/μl concentration.

components.data: If pooling several libraries, combine equal molar amounts.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: If pooling several libraries, combine equal molar amounts.

components.data:
Sequence your library on any compatible Illumina sequencer.

Dilute libraries to recommended molarity according to Illumina's recommendations (eg. 2 nM).

Select the following paired-end read-length settings:

 

Read Cycles Content
Read 1 16 Cell barcode & UMI
Index 1 8 i7 Index
Index 2 0  
Read 2 50 cDNA fragment
